Loud screamed the owl, and bats had winged their way,</br>From what the serious mind contemplates most;</br>From where the rural virgins fear to stray,</br>For moonlight shadow, or the stalking ghost.
In that lone spot, perhaps some beauty lies;</br>Whose form angelic moulders fast away;</br>No more, shall love reanimate her eyes,</br>Or voice recall her to the passing day.
Some tender pair, with dire disease opprest,</br>Whose lisping orphans scarce can tell their loss;</br>Some lovers, join'd in everlasting rest,</br>Some godlike Howard, or some Man of Ross.
And then, kind Anna, to the poor so dear;</br>No more shall smooth Affliction's thorny bed,</br>No more from Sorrow's cheek shall wipe the tear:</br>Alas!  she's number'd with the silent dead.

Clay-cold those hands which ever help'd Distress,</br>O why!  thou tyrant Death, this awful change?</br>Why strike thy arrow thro' the tenderest breast,</br>And leave the guilty wretch at large to range?
Th' emblazon'd monument erected nigh,</br>Perhaps contains some sordid flinty heart;</br>Whose breast ne'er felt the tender pitying sigh;</br>Or single mite for misery sat apart.
Ah!  what avails illustrious by birth?</br>Nor glittering star, nor coronet can save:</br>Alike the marble pile, or mound of earth,</br>The great and poor are equal in the grave.

Thou Power Supreme, mild heaven-born Virtue send;</br>O guide my heart to all that's good and great:</br>From malice, pride, and thoughtless vice defend,</br>And fit me for th' unknown, the certain state.</br>
